elements.content: The vanadyl oxalatophosphates (C2H10N2)[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4), 1, and (CH6N3)2[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4), 2, have been synthesized hydrothermally and characterized by a combination of techniques including infrared spectroscopy, single-crystal/powder X-ray diffraction, scanning/transmission electron microscopy, thermogravimetric analysis, and magnetic susceptibility measurements. The structures of 1 and 2 contain the same type of {[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4)}2- layer, including both oxalate and phosphate anions coordinated to vanadium cations, as found in the previously reported (NH4)2[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4)·H2O. Above ∼550 °C, 1 and 2 transform to (VO)2P2O7, the catalyst for the oxidation of butane to maleic anhydride. An intermediate phase with the composition VOHPO4 is observed in the decomposition reactions. Crystal data:  (1) triclinic, space group P1̄ (no. 2); a = 6.3595(7) Å, b = 6.6236(7) Å, c = 9.224(1) Å, α = 98.216(2)o, β = 108.128(2)o, γ = 100.672(2)o, V = 354.42(7) Å3, Z = 1; (2) triclinic, space group P1̄ (no. 2); a = 6.3825(8) Å, b = 7.8877(9) Å, c = 9.202(1) Å, α = 66.602(2)o, β = 71.757(2)o, γ = 79.821(2)o, V = 403.07(8) Å3, Z = 1.

The structures of 1 and 2 contain the same type of {[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4)}2- layer, including both oxalate and phosphate anions coordinated to vanadium cations, as found in the previously reported (NH4)2[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4)⋅H2O. Above ~550 °C, 1 and 2 transform to (VO)2P2O7, the catalyst for the oxidation of butane to maleic anhydride. elements.content: Vanadyl pyrophosphate, (VO)2P2O7, is an active and selective catalyst for the oxidation of butane to maleic anhydride. The catalyst is prepared in its optimum form by the topotactic transformation of hydrated layered vanadium hydrogen phosphates, such as the hemihydrate VOHPO4·0.5H2O. The topotactic decomposition preserves the precursor morphology and increases the area of the crystal faces that are thought to be responsible for the catalyst activity and selectivity. Some groups have suggested the presence of an amorphous intermediate in the transformation, but others consider this to be unlikely. Strain and domain size effects do, however, cause significant line broadening in X-ray diffraction patterns of samples annealed for short times just above the precursor decomposition temperature. The disorder has been interpreted as arising from stacking faults that are introduced when the layers become cross-linked on the formation of the pyrophosphate groups.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Vanadyl pyrophosphate, (VO)2P2O7, is an active and selective catalyst for the oxidation of butane to maleic anhydride. The catalyst is prepared in its optimum form by the topotactic transformation of hydrated layered vanadium hydrogen phosphates, such as the hemihydrate VOHPO4⋅0.5H2O. The topotactic decomposition preserves the precursor morphology and increases the area of the crystal faces that are thought to be responsible for the catalyst activity and selectivity. Some groups have suggested the presence of an amorphous intermediate in the transformation, but others consider this to be unlikely. Strain and domain size effects do, however, cause significant line broadening in X-ray diffraction patterns of samples annealed for short times just above the precursor decomposition temperature. The disorder has been interpreted as arising from stacking faults that are introduced when the layers become cross-linked on the formation of the pyrophosphate groups.

elements.content: In this paper, we describe the synthesis and characterization of two new vanadyl oxalatophosphate compounds ((C2H10N2)[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4), 1 , and (CH6N3)2[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4), 2 , containing the same type of {[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4)}2- layer previously found in (NH4)2[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4)·H2O. The thermal decomposition reactions of the two compounds give a previously unreported form of vanadyl hydrogen phosphate, VOHPO4, and provide an alternate route to (VO)2P2O7 catalysts.
elements.clean_text: In this paper, we describe the synthesis and characterization of two new vanadyl oxalatophosphate compounds ((C2H10N2)[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4), 1 , and (CH6N3)2[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4), 2 , containing the same type of {[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4)}2- layer previously found in (NH4)2[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4)⋅H2O. The thermal decomposition reactions of the two compounds give a previously unreported form of vanadyl hydrogen phosphate, VOHPO4, and provide an alternate route to (VO)2P2O7 catalysts.

elements.content: Synthesis. Compound 1 was synthesized by a two-step reaction. In the first step 17.4 g of V2O5 (0.0957 mol, Aldrich, 99%) was slowly added to a mixture of 18.12 g of oxalic acid (0.2012 mol, Aldrich, 98%), 34.6 mL of H3PO4 (0.5080 mol, Aldrich, 99.99%, 85 wt % solution in H2O), and 150 mL of distilled water at 70 °C. The solution was heated overnight at ∼100 °C. At this point no crystallization had occurred. The resulting blue solution (solution A) was used further as a reagent for the second step of the synthesis. This synthesis is based on the results of a systematic investigation of the formation of vanadyl phosphate hydrates by D. Fratzky et al. In the second step, 1 was prepared by heating 5 mL of solution A and 0.143 mL of ethylenediamine (2.1 mmol, Aldrich, 99%) at 120 °C under autogenous pressure for 4 d in a 23 mL capacity Teflon-lined stainless steel Parr hydrothermal bomb. The amounts of V, P, and C2O4 2- in 5 mL of solution A are 2.4, 12.7, and 5.0 mmol, respectively. Afterward, the reactor was cooled to room temperature over a 1 d period (final pH 0.62). The product was washed with water and dried in air. Green plate crystals (92% yield based on V) were obtained as a single phase.

Experimental Section

 Synthesis. Compound 1 was synthesized by a two-step reaction. In the first step 17.4 g of V2O5 (0.0957 mol, Aldrich, 99%) was slowly added to a mixture of 18.12 g of oxalic acid (0.2012 mol, Aldrich, 98%), 34.6 mL of H3PO4 (0.5080 mol, Aldrich, 99.99%, 85 wt % solution in H2O), and 150 mL of distilled water at 70 °C. The solution was heated overnight at ~100 °C. At this point no crystallization had occurred. The resulting blue solution (solution A) was used further as a reagent for the second step of the synthesis. This synthesis is based on the results of a systematic investigation of the formation of vanadyl phosphate hydrates by D. Fratzky et al. In the second step, 1 was prepared by heating 5 mL of solution A and 0.143 mL of ethylenediamine (2.1 mmol, Aldrich, 99%)  at 120 °C under autogenous pressure for 4 d in a 23 mL capacity Teflon-lined stainless steel Parr hydrothermal bomb. The amounts of V, P, and C2O4 2- in 5 mL of solution A are 2.4, 12.7, and 5.0 mmol, respectively. Afterward, the reactor was cooled to room temperature over a 1 d period (final pH 0.62). The product was washed with water and dried in air. Green plate crystals (92% yield based on V) were obtained as a single phase.

elements.content: Compound 2 was prepared by heating 3 mL of solution A, 3 mL of water, and 0.1351 g of guanidine carbonate (0.75 mmol, Aldrich, 99%) at 140 °C for 3 d. The amounts of V, P, and C2O4 2- in 3 mL of solution A are 1.4, 7.6, and 3.0 mmol, respectively. Afterward, the reactor was cooled to room temperature over 1 d (final pH 2.10). The product was washed with water and dried in air. Green plate crystals (87% yield based on V) were obtained as a single phase.

The product was washed with water and dried in air. Green plate crystals (87% yield based on V) were obtained as a single phase.

elements.content: Crystal Structure. The crystal structures of 1 and 2 were determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction methods. Preliminary examination and data collection were performed on a SMART platform diffractometer equipped with 1K CCD area detector using graphite-monochromatized Mo Kα radiation at room temperature. A hemisphere of data (1271 frames at a 5 cm detector distance) were collected using a narrow-frame method with scan widths of 0.30° in ω and an exposure time of 30 s/frame. The first 50 frames were remeasured at the end of data collection to monitor instrument and crystal stability, and the maximum correction applied to the intensities was <1%. The data were integrated using the Siemens SAINT program, with the intensities corrected for the Lorentz factor, polarization, air absorption, and absorption due to variation in the path length through the detector faceplate. The program SADABS was used for the absorption correction. Additional crystallographic details for 1 and 2 are described in Table .

The initial positions for some atoms were obtained by using direct methods. The structures were developed by using difference Fourier procedures and refined by full-matrix least-squares techniques with the use of the SHELXTL crystallographic software package. For 1, the final cycle of refinement performed on F o 2 with 1530 unique reflections afforded residuals R w = 0.0791 and R = 0.0321 [based on F o 2 > 2σ(F o 2)]. For 2, the final cycle of refinement performed on F o 2 with 1504 unique reflections afforded residuals R w = 0.1091 and R = 0.0449 [based on F o 2 > 2σ(F o 2)]. All of the hydrogen atoms for 1 and 2 were found by a difference Fourier synthesis and refined isotropically. No unusual trends were found in the goodness of fit as a function of F o 2, sin θ/λ, and Miller indices.

elements.content: Characterization. Powder X-ray data were collected on a Scintag XDS 2000 automated powder diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) equipped with a liquid N2 cooled germanium solid-state detector. Data were collected in the range 5° ≤ 2θ ≤ 80° using θ−θ methods in a flat-plate geometry with a horizontal stationary sample. Infrared spectra were recorded on a Mattson FTIR 5000 spectrometer within the range 800−4000 cm-1 using the KBr pellet method. Thermogravimetric analyses were carried out in air at a heating rate of 1°C/min, using a high-resolution TGA 2950 thermogravimetric analyzer (TA Instruments). Magnetic measurements were made with an Oxford Instruments vibrating sample magnetometer in the temperature range 4 < T (K) < 290 with an applied magnetic field of 1 T. A JEOL JSM-6330F scanning electron microscope and a JEOL 2000 FX transmission electron microscope were used to investigate the sample morphology.

elements.content: Structures. Atom positions and selected bond lengths and angles for both compounds are given in Tables and . The structures of 1 and 2 are isostructural with (NH4)2[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4)·H2O previously reported by us. In 1, each vanadium atom and phosphorus atom occupy one crystallographically unique position. The vanadium atom is coordinated by six oxygen atoms, forming a distorted octahedron. Three of the oxygen atoms are shared with three PO3OH groups with typical distances ranging from 1.964(2) from 2.006(2) Å. Two of the remaining oxygen atoms are shared with a C2O4 2- group with longer V−O distances of 2.077(2) and 2.259(2) Å. The remaining oxygen atom has a significantly shorter VO bond length of 1.602(2) Å (Figure ). Two vanadium octahedra are linked together by a C2O4 2- group to form [V2C2O12] dimers. Three of the oxygen atoms in the tetrahedral PO3OH group are shared with vanadium atoms, and the fourth oxygen atom is terminal with a long P−O distance, 1.587(2) Å, indicative of the P−OH group. The bonding between the [V2C2O12] dimers and PO3OH groups results in layers with composition {[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4)}2- as shown in Figure . Similar [VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4)2- layers are found in the structure of 2 (Figure ). The bond valence sum (BVS) values calculated for V are 4.10 and 4.05 for 1 and 2, respectively, in good agreement with the expected value of 4.00.

Results and Discussion

 Structures. Atom positions and selected bond lengths and angles for both compounds are given in Tables  and . The structures of 1 and 2 are isostructural with (NH4)2[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4)⋅H2O previously reported by us. In 1, each vanadium atom and phosphorus atom  occupy one crystallographically unique position. The vanadium atom is coordinated by six oxygen atoms, forming a distorted octahedron. Three of the oxygen atoms are shared with three PO3OH groups with typical distances ranging from 1.964(2) from 2.006(2) Å. Two of the remaining oxygen atoms are shared with a C2O4 2- group with longer V-O distances of 2.077(2) and 2.259(2) Å. The remaining oxygen atom has a significantly shorter VO bond length of 1.602(2) Å (Figure ). Two vanadium octahedra are linked together by a C2O4 2- group to form [V2C2O12] dimers. Three of the oxygen atoms in the tetrahedral PO3OH group are shared with vanadium atoms, and the fourth oxygen atom is terminal with a long P-O distance, 1.587(2) Å, indicative of the P-OH group. The bonding between the [V2C2O12] dimers and PO3OH groups results in layers with composition {[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4)}2- as shown in Figure . Similar [VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4)2- layers are found in the structure of 2 (Figure ). The bond valence sum (BVS) values calculated for V are 4.10 and 4.05 for 1 and 2, respectively, in good agreement with the expected value of 4.00.

The (enH2)2+ and (guanidiniumH)+ species are located in the space between the [(VO(HPO4)2(C2O4)] layers (Figure ). The ethylenediamineH2 cations are located in a 1̄ symmetry position between the [VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4) layers and are H-bonded with oxygen atoms in the layers (Figure a). Each nitrogen atom in the ethylenediammonium cation forms H-bonds with four oxygen atoms:  one terminal, O(7), atom in the PO4 unit, two, O(3) and O(5), atoms in oxalate, and one P−O−V-bridged, O(2), atom. In 2, the protonated guanidinium cations form H-bonds with seven neighboring oxygen atoms in the layers (Figure b):  one terminal, O(7), atom in the PO4 units, two, O(1) and O(5), atoms in the oxalate groups, and four V−O−P-bridged, O(2), O(3), and O(4), atoms (Figure b). The protonated guanidinium cations are oriented parallel to each other in the [100] direction. The distances between neighboring guanidinium cations are in the range 3.27−3.32 Å.

elements.content: Double [VO(HPO4)]2 chains are present within the layers. In these double chains, the terminal P−OH groups in VO(HPO4) chains point in opposite directions, along the [100] direction in both 1 and 2 (Figures a and ). A similar double VO(HPO4) chain is also found in the VO(HPO4)·4H2O structure, which is composed of infinite VO(HPO4)·2H2O chains containing H2O molecules coordinated to the vanadium atom. The double chains are also observed in the structure of (H2piperazine)0.5VOPO4, where they are joined by sharing common corners to give layers of composition [VOPO4].

elements.content: In the structures of 1 and 2, four V atoms, two P atoms, and two oxalate species form an eight-membered ring which has a center of inversion symmetry. The size of the eight-membered ring is 5.086 Å (O(1)···O(2)) by 6.359 Å (C(1)···C(1)) and 5.107 Å (O(2)···O(3)) by 6.382 Å (C(1)···C(1)) for 1 and 2, respectively (Figures a and ).The ∠VVV angles are 92.74° and 92.53° for 1 and 2, respectively.

elements.content: The most significant differences in the structures of 1, 2, and (NH4)2[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4)·H2O are the interlayer spacings and relative shifts of adjacent layers which arise from the steric and hydrogen-bonding requirements of each of the amines. The distances between layers are 6.556, 7.239, and 7.446 Å, and the layers are shifted by 0.947, 3.132, and 7.497 Å for 1, 2, and (NH4)2[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4)·H2O, respectively (Figure ).

The magnetic measurements were consistent with vanadium present as V4+. At temperatures in the range 10 < T (K) < 290, the samples are paramagnetic and obey the Curie−Weiss law with μeff = 1.72 and 1.73 μB for 1 and 2, respectively, close to the value expected for V4+(3d1, S = 1/2, μeff = 1.73 μB). Below 10 K, the V4+ magnetic moments begin to couple antiferromagnetically and the magnetic susceptibility goes through a maximum at ∼6 K.

elements.content: Thermal Transformations. The thermogravimetric analysis of 1 shows that the initial weight loss at ∼350 °C is due to the loss of the elements of ethylenediammonium oxalate (weight loss calcd 31.54%, exptl 30.40%). Thus, at this temperature, ∼400 °C, the intermediate has the composition VOHPO4. The evolution of the remaining proton as H2O from the structure is complete at ∼500 °C (final weight calcd 68.06%, exptl 68.03%). At this temperature, a weight increase is observed corresponding to the partial oxidation of V4+ to V5+ due to traces of oxygen in the balance. The final product is formed as a glassy residue.

elements.content: For 2, the TGA data show that the elements of guanidinium oxalate first evolve at ∼325 °C (weight loss calcd 38.97%, exptl 39.01%), a temperature range similar to that found for the decomposition of 1, leaving an intermediate with the composition VOHPO4. The evolution of the remaining proton as H2O from the structure is complete at ∼530 °C. Unlike 1, no weight gain is observed and the data quantitatively confirm the conversion of VOHPO4 to (VO)2P2O7 (weight loss calcd 3.37%, exptl 3.37%).

elements.content: To identify the final product after heat treatment, samples of 1 and 2 were heated in a tube furnace in N2 gas at a heating rate of ∼50 °C/min to 700 °C. Each sample was kept at 700 °C for 5 d and then cooled to room temperature. The final gray-colored residues were analyzed by powder X-ray diffraction. The powder diffraction patterns of 1 and 2 after this treatment are identical to that of (VO)2P2O7 as shown in Figure . The simulated data are based on the structure of (VO)2P2O7 reported by Nguyen et al.

elements.content:
The overall decomposition reactions based on the weight loss data are summarized below:

The structure of (VO)2P2O7 is closely related to the structures of 1 and 2. The unit cell of (VO)2P2O7 is monoclinic with lattice constants a = 7.7276(3) Å, b = 16.5885(4) Å, c = 9.5796(5) Å, and β = 89.975(3)°. The VPO layers are joined together through VOV and POP bonds, resulting in chains of vanadium octahedra sharing opposite corners and pyrophosphate groups. The structure of 1 and 2 in the ac plane is topologically related to that of (VO)2P2O7 in its bc plane.

elements.content: The structures of 1 and 2 can be transformed through several steps to give (VO)2P2O7:  removal of organoammonium cations between the layers together with removal of oxalate groups in the layers, rearrangement of the vanadium coordination environment, and condensation of vanadium and phosphate polyhedra. One possible mechanism for the transformation of the initial structure to the VOHPO4 intermediate is shown in Figure . The VOHPO3 chains are shown viewed down the crystallographic b axis of the starting structure, after the oxalate groups have been removed. The orientations of the VO and PO3OH groups are preserved when the two chains are linked by sharing the oxygen atoms as indicated by the arrows in Figure . The linking of two VO4 units from different chains can occur in a cooperative fashion and leads to the formation of V2O8 dimers composed of VO5 pyramids sharing a common edge. The bridging oxygen atoms in the dimers are also shared with phosphate oxygen atoms. The structural formula of the intermediate can be written as VO1/1O2/2O2/3PO2/2O1/3(OH)1/1 ≡ VOHPO4.

elements.content: In the final step, the VOHPO4 layers are cross-linked by condensation of the POH groups to form P2O7 4- on elimination of H2O and the formation of VOV bonds between the layers to give (VO)2P2O7. The overall decomposition reaction involves a significant reduction in volume, and the effect of this is shown in the scanning electron micrographs in Figure .The overall decomposition is pseudomorphous in that the initial rod-shaped crystal morphology of the oxalatophosphate is preserved. After the decomposition, the product is highly porous and consists of small platelike crystals of (VO)2P2O7.

elements.content: A number of experiments were performed to further investigate the intermediate phase. Samples of 1 and 2 were heated in a tube furnace in flowing N2 for reaction times varying from several hours to a month. The crystallinity varied, with samples prepared for a short time showing fewer, broader, and weaker lines than samples prepared for a long reaction time. The powder X-ray diffraction patterns of two examples of the intermediate phase are shown in Figure . The X-ray results for samples heated at 400 °C for 720 and 2 h are shown in parts a and b, respectively. Even after 2 h the sample shows significant crystallinity and becomes more crystalline on further annealing. The lines in the pattern after 720 h of annealing are, however, still broad but could be indexed by using the TREOR program. Two possible lattice systems were derived:  tetragonal (a = 12.793 Å, c = 8.606 Å) and monoclinic (a = 13.082 Å, b = 8.634 Å, c = 6.984 Å, β = 95.944°). However, attempts to solve the crystal structure using these unit cells were not successful. The differences between the observed and calculated peak positions are somewhat larger than expected, which may suggest that neither cell is correct (Table ).

Efforts were made to confirm the lattice parameters using electron diffraction from individual single crystals. The TEM micrographs show that the VOHPO4 intermediate is composed of very thin lamellae that overlap and are folded. Electron diffraction patterns from single crystals could not be obtained because of the overlapping crystals. X-ray analysis of samples in the microscope confirmed that the V/P ratio is 1.

elements.content: Finally, we note that the VOHPO4 intermediate described above is structurally different from a reported phase with the same composition. We have obtained previously a VOHPO4 phase related to β-VOPO4 from VPO4·H2O and the structure of a similar phase was determined by Wilde et al. from powder X-ray data.

elements.content: Guanidinium and ethylenediammonium vanadyl oxalatophosphates, (C2H10N2)[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4) and (CH6N3)2[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4), have been synthesized and characterized. Crystals of these compounds show a pseudomorphophic thermal transformation to vanadium pyrophosphate, (VO)2P2O7, from rod-shaped large crystals to tiny platy crystallites. A poorly crystalline phase, VOHPO4, is obtained as an intermediate during the thermal decomposition. The detailed structure of the intermediate has not been determined, but a possible mechanism for the decomposition is proposed on the basis of the structures of the end members.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Guanidinium and ethylenediammonium vanadyl oxalatophosphates, (C2H10N2)[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4) and (CH6N3)2[VO(HPO4)]2(C2O4), have been synthesized and characterized. Crystals of these compounds show a pseudomorphophic thermal transformation to vanadium pyrophosphate, (VO)2P2O7, from rod-shaped large crystals to tiny platy crystallites. A poorly crystalline phase, VOHPO4, is obtained as an intermediate during the thermal decomposition. The detailed structure of the intermediate has not been determined, but a possible mechanism for the decomposition is proposed on the basis of the structures of the end members.

cln_elements.content:
Synthesis. Compound 1 was synthesized by a two-step reaction. In the first step 17.4 g of V2O5 (0.0957 mol, Aldrich, 99%) was slowly added to a mixture of 18.12 g of oxalic acid (0.2012 mol, Aldrich, 98%), 34.6 mL of H3PO4 (0.5080 mol, Aldrich, 99.99%, 85 wt % solution in H2O), and 150 mL of distilled water at 70 °C. The solution was heated overnight at ∼100 °C. At this point no crystallization had occurred. The resulting blue solution (solution A) was used further as a reagent for the second step of the synthesis. This synthesis is based on the results of a systematic investigation of the formation of vanadyl phosphate hydrates by D. Fratzky et al. In the second step, 1 was prepared by heating 5 mL of solution A and 0.143 mL of ethylenediamine (2.1 mmol, Aldrich, 99%) at 120 °C under autogenous pressure for 4 d in a 23 mL capacity Teflon-lined stainless steel Parr hydrothermal bomb. The amounts of V, P, and C2O4 2- in 5 mL of solution A are 2.4, 12.7, and 5.0 mmol, respectively. Afterward, the reactor was cooled to room temperature over a 1 d period (final pH 0.62). The product was washed with water and dried in air. Green plate crystals (92% yield based on V) were obtained as a single phase.

Compound 2 was prepared by heating 3 mL of solution A, 3 mL of water, and 0.1351 g of guanidine carbonate (0.75 mmol, Aldrich, 99%) at 140 °C for 3 d. The amounts of V, P, and C2O4 2- in 3 mL of solution A are 1.4, 7.6, and 3.0 mmol, respectively. Afterward, the reactor was cooled to room temperature over 1 d (final pH 2.10). The product was washed with water and dried in air. Green plate crystals (87% yield based on V) were obtained as a single phase.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 Synthesis. Compound 1 was synthesized by a two-step reaction. In the first step 17.4 g of V2O5 (0.0957 mol, Aldrich, 99%) was slowly added to a mixture of 18.12 g of oxalic acid (0.2012 mol, Aldrich, 98%), 34.6 mL of H3PO4 (0.5080 mol, Aldrich, 99.99%, 85 wt % solution in H2O), and 150 mL of distilled water at 70 °C. The solution was heated overnight at ~100 °C. At this point no crystallization had occurred. The resulting blue solution (solution A) was used further as a reagent for the second step of the synthesis. This synthesis is based on the results of a systematic investigation of the formation of vanadyl phosphate hydrates by D. Fratzky et al. In the second step, 1 was prepared by heating 5 mL of solution A and 0.143 mL of ethylenediamine (2.1 mmol, Aldrich, 99%)  at 120 °C under autogenous pressure for 4 d in a 23 mL capacity Teflon-lined stainless steel Parr hydrothermal bomb. The amounts of V, P, and C2O4 2- in 5 mL of solution A are 2.4, 12.7, and 5.0 mmol, respectively. Afterward, the reactor was cooled to room temperature over a 1 d period (final pH 0.62). The product was washed with water and dried in air. Green plate crystals (92% yield based on V) were obtained as a single phase. 

Compound 2 was prepared by heating 3 mL of solution A, 3 mL of water, and 0.1351 g of guanidine carbonate (0.75 mmol, Aldrich, 99%) at 140 °C for 3 d. The amounts of V, P, and C2O4 2- in 3 mL of solution A are 1.4, 7.6, and 3.0 mmol, respectively. Afterward, the reactor was cooled to room temperature over 1 d (final pH 2.10). The product was washed with water and dried in air. Green plate crystals (87% yield based on V) were obtained as a single phase.

cln_elements.content: Thermal Transformations. The thermogravimetric analysis of 1 shows that the initial weight loss at ∼350 °C is due to the loss of the elements of ethylenediammonium oxalate (weight loss calcd 31.54%, exptl 30.40%). Thus, at this temperature, ∼400 °C, the intermediate has the composition VOHPO4. The evolution of the remaining proton as H2O from the structure is complete at ∼500 °C (final weight calcd 68.06%, exptl 68.03%). At this temperature, a weight increase is observed corresponding to the partial oxidation of V4+ to V5+ due to traces of oxygen in the balance. The final product is formed as a glassy residue.
